title: When, if ever, should a company be permitted to refuse to do business with a person because of that person's public statements?
intro: In this analysis, I explore the legal boundaries of businesses refusing service in the U.S., focusing on how federal and state laws intersect with societal values. Through cases like the Virginia restaurant denying service to a Trump official, Colorado’s Masterpiece Cakeshop dispute, and a New York bar rejecting a MAGA-hat-wearing patron, I dissect how protected traits—race, religion, political affiliation—shape these decisions.

title: Should we ban billionaires?
intro: In the essay, I argue that billionaire wealth perpetuates inequality through monopolies and media control, yet outright bans risk economic harm. Analyzing tax strategies and Norway’s equitable model, I propose targeted reforms. Justice lies not in erasing wealth but in redistributing its power responsibly.

title: Flying to a better world
intro: This article explores the aviation industry's environmental chanllenges and the road to transformation. For a long time, in the face of carbon emissions and fuel prices continue to rise, the urgency of climate change, experts are figuring out more sustainable materials. The road is long, but it is inevitable.

title: Sanctions, Energy, Sovereignty: How Has the Russia-Ukraine War Reshaped the Global Economic Order?
intro: In this article, I analyze the complex effects of the Russian-Ukrainian war on the global economy. As a witness, I believe that deepening independent development is not only the revelation of the crisis, but also the key to breaking the situation.

title: Silent Heros in Pandemic
intro: I write down my parents' persistence during the epidemic, not only to remember their dedication across the isolation but also to convey the light in the dark night - ordinary heroes with sweat and patience, weaving the color of reunion.

title: Grandpa and Wood
intro: A eulogy to my grandpa who taught me dedication and passion for life.

title: I though I could keep autumn
intro: I realized that some things in life are just like quicksand. The tighter you hold them, the faster they dissipate. Learning to let go gracefully is just as important as holding on firmly.

title: My greatest fear
intro: A pour-out after watching a documentary. I discussed the confusion and anxiety of growing up, and my biggest fear.

title: The Rust of the Tin Frog
intro: It was my first time writing a fiction.  In the story, every image—the rusted frog, the cracked seashells, the wandering hermit crabs—was a reflection of longing, of grasping at remnants of love that time had eroded.  I wanted the narrative to feel like the sea itself: vast, relentless, and full of whispers from the past.
